title: Altuve’s Homer Stuns Yankees and Sends Astros to World Series
text:
Facing these questions on Sunday morning will be more painful considering the Yankees had a clear opportunity to write a different ending. Entering the day, Saturday’s game was basically a coin flip. The Astros declined to use Cole, who was lined up for a potential Game 7 on regular rest. Both teams emptied their bullpens for Game 6, and the game dragged as both managers tried to carefully navigate through matchups and jams.

But ultimately, Game 6 was a microcosm of how the Yankees were betrayed by many facets of their play this series.

Their pitching sputtered in key moments. Though the Yankees had the stronger bullpen — often a major factor in October — the Astros alleviated the load on their weaker relief corps by riding the three aces of their starting rotation. The Yankees’ two wins this series came in the only games in which their starters completed five innings.

As a result, even more pressure heaped on the Yankees’ bullpen, and Adam Ottavino, Chad Green and Tommy Kahnle — all reliable, workhorse relievers during the regular season — faltered. Green, who started Saturday’s game, surrendered a double to Altuve, walked Alex Bregman and then gave up a three-run blast to Yuli Gurriel in the first inning. Kahnle, having pitched in eight of the Yankees’ nine games this postseason, looked like he was running out of steam as he labored through a critical sixth inning on Saturday.

The Yankees’ defense was shaky at times, from catcher Gary Sanchez’s repeated troubles stopping balls to a costly mistake in the sixth inning. Trailing by one run and with runners on the corners, Yankees Manager Aaron Boone didn’t move the infield in. And when Bregman hit a ground ball, Gregorius hesitated just enough when he looked at Altuve at third base that Bregman beat out the double play at first base. It allowed Altuve to score and pushed the Astros’ lead to 4-2.
description: Minutes after D.J. LeMahieu tied the game in the top of the ninth, Jose Altuve hit a game-winning home run in the bottom half to send the Astros to the World Series and end the Yankees’ season.
